comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: The work completed on this section of track on this day, Wednesday 8 August 1906, considerably helped improve the significant delays experienced by passengers on Monday 6 August, the first business day after the new station officially opened on Saturday 4 August. THE SYDNEY RAILWAY STATION. OPENING CEREMONY. SENDING OFF THE FIRST TRAIN. AN AUSPICIOUS EVENT. - The Sydney Morning Herald, Monday 6 August 1906, p.7. THE SYDNEY RAILWAY STATION. TRAFFIC DISORGANISED. - The Sydney Morning Herald, Tuesday 7 August 1906, p.5. THE SYDNEY RAILWAY STATION. TRAFFIC CONDITIONS IMPROVED. AN OFFICIAL STATEMENT. - The Sydney Morning Herald, Wednesday 8 August 1906, p.12. THE SYDNEY RAILWAY STATION. CONDITION OF THE TRAFFIC. MARKED IMPROVEMENT IN THE ARRANGEMENTS - The Sydney Morning Herald, Thursday 9 August 1906, p.7. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/] John, was Charles Cowper an ancestor of yours? I like his sentiment expressed in a letter to the editor ... THE RAILWAY STATION OPENING. TO THE EDITOR OF THE HERALD. - "those who have been complaining of the delays in the late emergency should have thought of what they had to thank the raliway enthusiasts of 1855 for, and the care the Railway Commissioners, their officers, and men were at that very moment taking to ensure their safety. As I looked over the railway station and witnessed the great work of removing buildings and laying down fresh lines, many men working day and night, I could not help wondering how any traveller could allow a murmur to escape his lips. Instead of finding fault we should rather congratulate the Railway Department for its wonderful success." - The Sydney Morning Herald, Monday 13 August 1906, p.4.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47201412@N02] Yes, Charles was my great grandfather, at the time he was retired, having been the NSW Sheriff and Water Police Magistrate - they lived on Cockatoo Island during my grandfather's schooldays. In regards to the letter, we have it on file and just shows that we have always protected our own! His father was also Charles (later Sir Charles) who was one of the instigators of the Sydney Railway Company (1848-1857) and also Premier of NSW five times. Here are their pictures Charles (Snr) # Charles (Jnr) # Like his father Charles Junior had been a member of parliament. (Both pictures from the Cowper Family archives) You can read more about Charles Snr here [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/2095113296] There are also extensive pieces on the NSW Parliament website and the Australian Dictionary of Biography website. We also have a family website: www.Cowper200.com.au

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Aha! That's quite an illustrious lineage to live up to :) Another Flickr contact, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/18901029@N00] Don Shearman, also has a family connection to Cockatoo Island - his great grandfather John Pratt was Dockmaster.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This is the Second Sydney Station seen from the Third - www.cityrail.info/about/history/central_station_in-depth . Just to confuse completely there was almost another Sydney Station - "No. Two-and-a-half" ? - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5207836758/]
